intro: Brassica campestris var. genuina, commonly known as field mustard, is a flowering plant in the family Brassicaceae. It is characterized by its erect, leafy stems and yellow flowers that form clusters at the ends of the branches. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–100 cm and has alternate, lobed or pinnate leaves. Its seeds are small, oval, and often contain a high amount of glucosinolates, which are sulfur-containing compounds. This variety is native to Europe and is often found in disturbed soils, roadsides, and agricultural fields.
